newsitem.title: CHINA: China to invest more in Xinjiang oil exploration.
newsitem.headline: China to invest more in Xinjiang oil exploration.

text.p: China is planning to invest a huge sum of money in oil exploration in the three major basins of its northwestern Xinjiang region in the next five years, the Xinhua news agency said in an overnight report.
It gave no details of the size of the investment.

Howver, the investment represented the government's largest commitment to turning Xinjiang into a major oil production base, it quoted Zhou Yongkang, Vice President of the China National Petroleum Corp, as saying.

According to a nationwide study, the Tarim, Turfan-Hami and Junggar basins, along with other basins in Xinjiang, had total resources of 20.86 billion tonnes of oil and 10.3 trillion cubic metres of gas, accounting for 30 percent of China's total continental reserves, Xinhua said.
By the end of last year, the region had verified reserves of 1.94 billion tonnes of oil and 356.7 billion cubic metres of gas but there was still potential for more exploration, Xinhua said.
Xinjiang pumped 12 million tonnes of crude oil last year, accounting for nine percent of China's total.
With larger investment over the next five years, Xinjiang is expected to have annual crude output of 23 million tonnes by the turn of the century, or 16 percent of China's total.
